channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Kevin Niu on Movies and the Hunger for Horror in China
item.description: Despite being about to receive his Ph.D. in physics from Harvard, Kevin Niu plans to eschew the academic life to follow his calling in the entertainment industry.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Kevin Niu, Ph.D. student in physics and producer of the horror movie "Abattoir."

item.title: Europe Takes Stronger Measures, Albeit Symbolic, to Condemn Israeli Policies
item.description: After years of growing frustration, European politicians are embracing symbolic steps to support a Palestinian state.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Musa Amer Odeh, with scarf, the Palestinian delegate to Spain, after Spanish lawmakers passed a nonbinding motion to recognize Palestine once it and Israel negotiate an end to their conflict.

item.title: An Ethnic Chinese Christian, Breaking Barriers in Indonesia
item.description: Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, the new leader of Jakarta, the capital of the most populous Muslim-majority nation, says his faith and ethnicity are not political handicaps.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: The governor of Jakarta, Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, center, runs the capital of the world’s most populous Muslim-majority nation.

item.title: With Borscht and Rifle Scopes, Volunteers Power Ukraine Forces
item.description: Volunteers are offering not only support but at least a glimmer of hope that poorly funded Ukrainian government troops can hold their own.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Dnipro-1 volunteer battalion in Pervomaisk, Ukraine.

item.title: News Analysis: Mistrust Threatens Delicate Balance at a Sacred Site in Jerusalem
item.description: A site in the Old City of Jerusalem, known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary, has been a flash point since the advent of modern Zionism.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Jews standing before a stairway leading to the Dome of the Rock, part of a mosque in the Old City of Jerusalem that sits on ground holy to both Jews and Muslims.

item.title: G.O.P.-Led Benghazi Panel Bolsters Administration
item.description: The House Intelligence Committee has joined previous panels in rejecting the most damning accusations about the handling of the 2012 attacks on American outposts.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: News Analysis: Asia’s ‘Big Guy’ Spreads Cash and Seeks Influence in Pacific Region
item.description: As China seeks to assert itself as the dominant economic power and strategic partner in Asia, President Xi Jinping has visited Australia, New Zealand and Fiji bestowing largess.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China received a traditional Maori greeting in Wellington, New Zealand, last week. Mr. Xi also visited Australia and Fiji.

item.title: In Iran Talks, U.S. Seeks to Prevent a Covert Weapon
item.description: Unstated during negotiations is the fear of a “sneakout,” the risk of a bomb being produced at an undetected facility, or built from fuel and components obtained from one of Iran’s few trading partners.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: A view of the mountain where Iran built a hidden centrifuge facility called Fordo. The U.S. revealed its existence in 2009.

item.title: Hour’s Drive Outside Kabul, Taliban Reign
item.description: In the absence of international troops or their air support, the Taliban have eclipsed the legitimacy of government forces in several parts of the country.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Andrew Quilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan forces responding in August after a Humvee was ambushed by the Taliban in the Tagab district of Kapisa Province.

item.title: Opinion: Jerusalem’s Train to Nowhere
item.description: Instead of normal urban life, a trail of blood.
item.dc:creator: By EETTA PRINCE-GIBSON
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerusalem’s light rail trams, once a haven of normality, have come under attack in recent months.

item.title: Earthquake in Western China Kills at Least One Person and Injures 15
item.description: The quake struck in a lightly populated, mountainous area of Sichuan Province.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Thousands of Iraq Chemical Weapons Destroyed in Open Air, Watchdog Says
item.description: A report by a watchdog group reveals the United States recovered thousands of chemical weapons in Iraq from 2004 to 2009 and destroyed almost all of them in secret and via open-air detonation.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By C.J. CHIVERS

item.title: Shabab Gunmen Attack Bus in Kenya and Kill 28
item.description: The Somalian insurgent group attacked a bus in northeastern Kenya and killed passengers who were not Muslims, saying they were responding to raids by Kenyan forces on four mosques.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Madagascar: Plague Outbreak Kills 40
item.description: The World Health Organization reported that an outbreak of plague, the infamous scourge that killed millions in the Dark Ages, has been recorded in parts of Madagascar.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Suddenly, Sri Lanka Presidential Elections Become a Real Contest
item.description: In a surprise, the president’s health minister, who also was the general secretary of the ruling party, quit to run as the opposition candidate.
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: In Zimbabwe’s Succession Battle, Mugabe Pulls the Strings
item.description: President Robert Mugabe is presiding over — and possibly choreographing — an increasingly fierce internal scramble for the rewards of high office.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe and his wife, Grace, in Harare, the capital, in October. Mr. Mugabe, 90, is Africa’s oldest leader.

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: 12 Are Injured in Blast at Hotel
item.description: More than a dozen were hurt in what the police said they suspected was a natural-gas explosion in the basement of a central London hotel just before midnight Friday.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: In a Shift, Obama Extends U.S. Role in Afghan Combat
item.description: President Obama’s order would allow American forces to carry out missions against the Taliban and other militant groups threatening American troops or the Afghan government, sources said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: As Immigration Rules Shift, Migrants’ Joy Is Tempered
item.description: Some expressed confusion about how they would obtain the new documents that would allow them to obtain work permits under the president’s plan. And immigrants who came here legally expressed betrayal.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: Oscar Alfaro hugs his aunt, Carmen Paz, at a Maryland event for the president’s address.

item.title: Brinkmanship Heightens as Deadline for a Nuclear Deal With Iran Looms
item.description: Difficulties in the talks suggested it was unlikely that any agreement that might be announced on Monday would be a complete one, and that a deadline extension would be needed.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry left a meeting in Vienna on Friday where negotiations on a nuclear deal with Iran are being held.

item.title: In Change of Strategy, China Cuts Interest Rate
item.description: The step suggests that policy makers have become nervous about the pace at which growth is slowing, though analysts said the change’s effect would be small.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: A job fair in Shanghai on Thursday. China's interest rate cut reflects concern that the economy is growing too slowly.

item.title: Officials Revise Goals on Containing Ebola After Signs of Wider Exposure in Mali
item.description: The leaders of the United Nations and the World Health Organization said nearly 500 people in Mali and Guinea had been exposed to a sickened imam who had been misdiagnosed.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Dispatch: Tiptoeing Through Kurdistan
item.description: The hospitality is overwhelming, but so are the grievances and the conflicts.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL SALOPEK
item.media:description: Kurds at the funerals in Turkey of three Kurdish fighters who died last month in clashes in Syria with the Islamic State.

item.title: House Intel Panel Debunks Many Benghazi Theories
item.description: A two-year investigation by the Republican-controlled House Intelligence Committee found that the C.I.A. and military acted properly in responding to the attack on a U.S. diplomatic compound in Benghazi.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ISIS Taunts United States and Britain in New Video
item.description: In a video released Friday, John Cantlie, a British journalist being held by the Islamic State, called on the United States and Britain to negotiate prisoner swaps or pay ransoms.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
